content.div:
Every country needs an anthem -- even a dystopian republic like the Hunger Games' Panem. And while there's a veritable cornucopia of reasons why we're thankful Panem doesn't actually exist (reality TV is fun and all, but we draw the line at watching live-to-air slaughter), Suzanne Collins' sci-fi state is arguably cooler than most. Panem's national anthem, for instance, is written by the Arcade Fire.

The song, "Abraham's Daughter," premiered today via Entertainment Weekly, weeks ahead of the Hunger Games Soundtrack's March 20 release. Propelled by the marching beat of a military snare, the Montreal band's Regine Chassagne takes the lead vocal, eerily singing about an even eerier topic: the biblical story of Abraham and Isaac (albeit with a female, Hunger Games-appropriate twist).

Arcade Fire's Win Butler spoke to Entertainment Weekly about the creation of the song. "Our whole approach was to get into the world and try to create something that serves the story and the film,” he said. ”There’s something in the story of Abraham and Isaac that I think resonates with the themes in the film, like sacrificing children. So we made a weird, alternate-universe version of that, where it’s as if Abraham had a daughter -- kind of a metaphor for Katniss," he continued, referring to the Hunger Games' heroine, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), a teenage girl who volunteers to take her younger sister's place in the Hunger Games, an annual tournament that pits teens from Panem's 12 districts against each other in a fight to the death.

“We were interested in making music that would be more integral in the movie, just as a mental exercise,” Butler told EW. “And there’s an anthem that runs throughout the books, the national anthem of the fascist Capitol. So as a thought experiment, we tried to write what that might sound like. It’s like the Capitol’s idea of itself, basically.

“It’s not a pop song or anything,” he continued. “More of an anthem that could be playing at a big sporting event like the Games. So we did a structure for that, and then James Newton Howard made a movie-score version of it that happens in several places in the film.”

That said, Butler explained that "Abraham's Daughter" will appear during the film's end credits. "I tried to put myself in the headspace of how excited I’d be if this film was coming out when I was 15. I still remember hearing Radiohead’s ‘Exit Music (for a Film)’ in [Baz Luhrmann’s] Romeo + Juliet when I was that age,” he said.

As previously reported, Arcade Fire will contribute two songs to the Hunger Games Soundtrack, "Abraham's Daughter" and an orchestral piece called "Horn of Plenty." Other artists featured on the soundtrack include Miranda Lambert, The Decemberists and Taylor Swift, whose soundtrack single "Safe and Sound" features in a just-released preview of the upcoming sci-fi flick.

The Hunger Games arrives in theaters March 23.

Listen to "Abraham's Daughter" below:

leahc@dose.ca

link.Abstract: Taylor Swift always looks surprised in photos. But here's some news that really deserves an OMG-face: Swift was forced to cancel a series of concert dates due to bronchitis. Yikes! Get well soon, Swifty. It's time you built up your strength. Here, have a sandwich. In fact, have 10. We hope Swift's feeling better in time for her July 14 show in Montreal.
link.title: Gallery: Eat a Sandwich, Taylor Swift

entry.title: Who's Cuter: Liam Hemsworth or a Squirrel?

link.Abstract: If we learned one thing from Liam Hemsworth's Details interview, it's that the dude is easily distracted by squirrels. Funny, we're easily distracted by Liam Hemsworth. But who's cuter?! We're pretty sure we know how the Hunger Games star will be voting, but we'll let you decide. For each slide, cast your vote!
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Taylor Swift and The Civil Wars debuted their Hunger Games music video "Safe & Sound." Check it out here, along with the movie soundtrack's full tracklisting, which features contributions from Arcade Fire and The Decemberists.
